root.pub-comments: “Nearly all of these groups are internally divergent” (Rensch 1976:7).
root.publications: Rensch, Calvin R. 1976. Comparative Otomanguean Phonology, 350. Bloomington, Indiana: Indiana University.

child.pub-comments: “Lehmann was the first to point out the close relationship between Subtiaba, of Nicaragua, and Tlapanec, of Mexico. This point of view was accepted by Sapir, who stated that 'Subtiaba and Tlappanec are really only dialect of a single language'” (Rensch 1977:76). “It is here proposed that the similarities between Subtiaba-Tlapanec and the languages of the Mixtec-Zapotec-Otomi group noticed by Sapir are due not to areal diffusion but, rather, to development from a common ancestor language. It is further claimed that that ancestor language was Proto Otomanguean […]” (Rensch 1977:77).
child.publications: Oltrogge, David Frederick & Calvin R. Rensch. 1977. Two studies in Middle American comparative linguistics, 108.
Oltrogge, David Frederick & Calvin R. Rensch. 1977. Two studies in Middle American comparative linguistics, 108.

child.pub-comments: Editor's note: In Rensch 1976, Tlapanec was not discussed because of limited data, but in 1977, Rensch included Tlapanec in Otomanguean. Since Rensch is unclear where Tlapanec should be placed within Otomanguean, Tlapanec has been placed as a daughter of Otomanguean. “...the limited data available in print on Tlapanec suggest that that language also may be a part of Otomanguean. Because of the lack of data Tlapanec has not been incorporated into the present study, but it is expected that further data will make its inclusion possible” (Rensch 1976:8). “Thus, the present conclusion is that Tlapanec is most like Proto Zapotecan, especially Zapotec, from the standpoint of both structural innovations and phonetic shifts. Proto Chiapanec-Mangue and Proto Mixtecan seem to be removed from Tlapanec by successive degrees of separation but still are significantly more like Tlapanec than are the other groups within Otomanguean” (Rensch 1977:95).
child.publications: Oltrogge, David Frederick & Calvin R. Rensch. 1977. Two studies in Middle American comparative linguistics, 108.
Rensch, Calvin R. 1976. Comparative Otomanguean Phonology, 350. Bloomington, Indiana: Indiana University.
